mentions.context: MOSAIC is an acronym for MOdelling and StAtistical tools for ecotoxICology, that can be accessed through any Internet browser at https://mosaic.univ-lyon1.fr/

MOSAIC offers two services related to the use of GUTS-RED models to analyze standard survival data as function of both time and exposure concentration: MOSAIC GU T S-f it for step (1) and MOSAIC GU T S-predict for steps
MOSAIC GU T S-predict has been developed in R (R Core Team, 2021) within a Shiny environment (Chang et al., 2021).
(MOSAIC, 2013).
All MOSAIC modules make available a collection of example data sets, allowing new users to practice using the various features.
MOSAIC GU T S-predict has been developed in R (R Core Team, 2021) within a Shiny environment (Chang et al., 2021).
All features of MOSAIC GU T S-f it have already been detailed in Baudrot et al. (2018b).

At last, we show how MOSAIC can be of valuable help to fully complete the EFSA workflow regarding the use of TKTD models, especially with GUTS models, providing a user-friendly interface for calibrating, validating and predicting survival over time under any time-variable exposure scenario of interest.

Available since 2013, MOSAIC first proposed a service for SSD analyses via MOSAIC SSD (Kon Kam King et al., 2014;MOSAICssd, 2013)  (MOSAICguts-fit, 2018) in combination with MOSAIC GU T S-predict (MOSAICgutspredict, 2018;Baudrot et al., 2018b).
In the following subsection, MOSAIC GU T S-predict is presented in details, in support of the validation and the prediction steps of the EFSA workflow.
MOSAIC is an acronym for MOdelling and StAtistical tools for ecotoxICology, that can be accessed through any Internet browser at https://mosaic.univ-lyon1.fr/
1 To access to the very last version of MOSAIC bioacc that is regularly updated and tested before to be deployed on the official server, please go to https://scharles-univlyon1.
Several updates were recently implemented in MOSAIC bioacc .

At last, in 2020, two last services were offered: (i) MOSAIC growth (MOSAICgrowth, 2020) delivering EC x estimates from standard continuous data (such as length, weight, growth rate,...), making then available a full suite of services for standard analyses whatever the type of data collected via standard toxicity tests (Charles et al., 2021); (ii) MOSAIC bioacc (MOSAICbioacc, 2020) fitting a variety of TK models accounting for several routes of exposure, several elimination processes and several phase-I metabolites from one parent compound (Ratier et al., 2019), from which bioaccumulation factors are automatically derived (Ratier et al., 2020).

When performing standard analyses of toxicity test data in MOSAIC, the mean tendency of the relationship between the observed endpoints and the tested concentrations is first described by a 3-parameters log-logistic model written as follows:
Among available modelling tools dedicated to ecotoxicity, the MOSAIC platform proposes a suite of services within an all-in-one web site.

The purpose of this article is to present all the features of MOSAIC in order to guide academics, manufacturers and regulators to benefit from advanced and sound models in ERA in support of their daily work, meeting all expectations in terms of regulatory requirements.
The section below illustrates the use of the last updated version of MOSAIC bioacc .
Note that the entire analysis can be identically reproduced using the MOSAIC platform.

Available since 2013, MOSAIC first proposed a service for SSD analyses via MOSAIC SSD (Kon Kam King et al., 2014;MOSAICssd, 2013)  (MOSAICguts-fit, 2018) in combination with MOSAIC GU T S-predict (MOSAICgutspredict, 2018;Baudrot et al., 2018b).
12 Availability of data All data used in this paper are downloadable from the MOSAIC web platform.
The next subsection guides the reader step by step to perform the EFSA workflow directly using MOSAIC.
The first section gives insights on classical DR analyses, focusing on the last new-born service MOSAIC growth .
Then, we focus on the necessity to account for the time-dimension of the exposure by illustrating how MOSAIC can support a robust calculation of bioaccumulation factors.

In this paper, we first propose a brief review of classical dose-response models to put into light the on-line MOSAIC tool offering all necessary services in a turnkey web platform whatever the type of data to analyze.
Such situations today benefit from both a unified modelling framework (Ratier et al., 2019) and a ready-to-use tool, MOSAIC bioacc (Ratier et al., 2020).

MOSAIC offers two services related to the use of GUTS-RED models to analyze standard survival data as function of both time and exposure concentration: MOSAIC GU T S-f it for step (1) and MOSAIC GU T S-predict for steps

Available since 2013, MOSAIC first proposed a service for SSD analyses via MOSAIC SSD (Kon Kam King et al., 2014;MOSAICssd, 2013)  (MOSAICguts-fit, 2018) in combination with MOSAIC GU T S-predict (MOSAICgutspredict, 2018;Baudrot et al., 2018b).

MOSAIC offers two services related to the use of GUTS-RED models to analyze standard survival data as function of both time and exposure concentration: MOSAIC GU T S-f it for step (1) and MOSAIC GU T S-predict for steps

This data collection is presented as a table that summarises the main characteristics of the data (genus, category, substance, accumulation duration, exposure routes, number of data and replicates), as well as a direct link to the reference, and direct links to download the raw data and the full report provided by MOSAIC bioacc .

At last, in 2020, two last services were offered: (i) MOSAIC growth (MOSAICgrowth, 2020) delivering EC x estimates from standard continuous data (such as length, weight, growth rate,...), making then available a full suite of services for standard analyses whatever the type of data collected via standard toxicity tests (Charles et al., 2021); (ii) MOSAIC bioacc (MOSAICbioacc, 2020) fitting a variety of TK models accounting for several routes of exposure, several elimination processes and several phase-I metabolites from one parent compound (Ratier et al., 2019), from which bioaccumulation factors are automatically derived (Ratier et al., 2020).
